question: Question_01_(n)
statement:
Find the variance of the random variable \emph{X} whose density function
is

\[f(x) = \frac1{2\sqrt{x}} \quad 1 \leq x \leq 4.\]

\emph{(You may need the fact that the expected value of the random
variable X above is 7/3.)}
sols:
From the definition of the variance we can directly compute its value.

\begin{align*}
\mathrm{Var}(X) &= \int_a^b (x-\overline{X})^2 f(x)\, dx = \int_1^4 \left(x-\frac73\right)^2 \frac1{2\sqrt{x}}\,dx \\
&= \int_1^4 \left(\frac{x^2}{2\sqrt{x}} - \frac73 \frac{x}{\sqrt{x}} + \frac{49}9 \frac1{2\sqrt{x}}\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_1^4 \left(\frac12 x^{3/2} - \frac73 x^{1/2} + \frac{49}{18}x^{-1/2}\right)\,dx \\
&= \left.\left(\frac12 \frac25 x^{5/2} - \frac73 \frac23 x^{3/2} + \frac{49}{18} 2x^{1/2}\right)\right|_1^4 \\
&= \frac15\,32 - \frac{14}9\,8 + \frac{49}9\,2 - \left(\frac15 - \frac{14}9 + \frac{49}9\right) \\
&= \frac{34}{45}.
\end{align*}

Alternatively, we can also use the identity

\[\mathrm{Var}(X) = \mathbb{E}(X^2) - (\mathbb{E}(X))^2.\]

We're already given $\mathbb{E}(X) = 7/3$ so we just need
$\mathbb{E}(X^2) = \int_1^4 x^2 f(x) dx$.

We compute this integral, finding
$\mathbb{E}(X^2) = \int_1^4 x^2 \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} dx = \int_1^4 \frac{1}{2} x^{3/2} dx = \frac{1}{5} x^{5/2}|_1^4 = \frac{1}{5}(32-1) = 31/5.$

Thus $\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{31}{5} - (\frac{7}{3})^2 = 34/45$.
